G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: This Court has subject-matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4, because the amount in controversy exceeds $25,000, exclusive of interest and costs.

**Mounsey v. Ellard**, 363 Mass. 693, 70.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that motorists and persons exiting vehicles owe a duty of reasonable care to others lawfully using the public way, including bicyclists.
**Mounsey v. Ellard**, 363 Mass. 693, 70.support_reasoning: The provided excerpt from Mounsey v. Ellard concerns premises liability and the treatment of trespassers, licensees, and invitees. It does not address duties of motorists or persons exiting vehicles, nor does it mention bicyclists or public way traffic obligations. Therefore, this case, at least in the cited portion, does not support the specific proposition about motorists’ duties to bicyclists on public ways.
**Mounsey v. Ellard**, 363 Mass. 693, 70.relevant_excerpt: "The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a ‘licensee’ rather than an ‘invitee,’ or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. But footnote 7 seems to say that ‘trespassers’ stand apart, that that characterization is to remain decisive or highly influential."

**Beck v. Lenzi**, 18 Mass. App. Ct. 928.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that motorists and persons exiting vehicles owe a duty of reasonable care to others lawfully using the public way, including bicyclists.
**Beck v. Lenzi**, 18 Mass. App. Ct. 928.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns criminal convictions for indecent assault, battery, and statutory rape of a child, addressing issues such as fresh complaint testimony, prosecutorial argument, jury instructions on lesser included offenses, consent, and reasonable doubt. It does not involve motor vehicle operation, people exiting vehicles, public ways, or bicyclists, nor does it discuss any duty of care in that context. Therefore, it provides no authority for the proposition about motorists’ or exiting passengers’ duties to others on the public way.
**Beck v. Lenzi**, 18 Mass. App. Ct. 928.relevant_excerpt: No portion of the opinion discusses motorists, vehicles, duties owed to others on a public way, pedestrians, or bicyclists; the case is entirely about sexual offenses against a child and related evidentiary and instructional issues.

G.L. c. 90, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under G.L. c. 90, § 14, “[n]o person shall open a door on a motor vehicle unless it is reasonably safe to do so without interfering with the movement of other traffic, including bicyclists,” and no person shall leave a door open on the side of a vehicle available to moving traffic “for a period of time longer than necessary to load or unload passengers.”

**Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store,.raw_text: **Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.**, 408 Mass. 355, 358–59 (1990)
**Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store,.proposition: Violation of a statute intended to protect public safety, while not negligence per se in Massachusetts, is evidence of negligence.
**Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store,.case_name: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.
**Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store,.support_reasoning: The opinion directly discusses the effect of violating G.L. c. 138, § 69 and reiterates the Massachusetts rule that such a statutory violation is not negligence per se but is only some evidence of negligence. The court explicitly frames violation of § 69 as “only ‘some evidence’ of the defendant’s negligence,” aligning squarely with the proposition that a safety statute violation is evidence of negligence but not conclusive of it.
**Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store,.relevant_excerpt: “It has long been the rule in this Commonwealth that violation of a statute does not by itself establish a breach of duty, for it does not constitute negligence per se. LaClair v. Silberline Mfg. Co., 379 Mass. 21, 28 (1979), and cases cited. Rather, violation of a statute such as § 69 is only ‘some evidence’ of the defendant's negligence as to all consequences the statute was intended to prevent. Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., supra. Adamian v. Three Sons, Inc., 353 Mass. 498, 499 (1968).”

**Orcutt v. Miller**, 201 Mass. 432, 437.proposition: Violation of a statute intended to protect public safety, while not negligence per se in Massachusetts, is evidence of negligence.
**Orcutt v. Miller**, 201 Mass. 432, 437.case_name: Dooley v. Boston Elevated Railway Co.
**Orcutt v. Miller**, 201 Mass. 432, 437.support_reasoning: The opinion excerpt concerns evidentiary and instructional issues about damages for hysterical fits following a trolley accident. It does not discuss violation of any statute, public safety legislation, negligence per se, or the evidentiary effect of statutory violations in negligence actions. Therefore, this case does not provide authority for the proposition that violation of a public-safety statute is evidence of negligence in Massachusetts rather than negligence per se.
**Orcutt v. Miller**, 201 Mass. 432, 437.relevant_excerpt: In this state of the evidence the defendant asked the judge to give the following instructions: "7. If under the instructions of the court the jury finds that there was such physical injury in this case as to permit the recovery of damages for mental suffering or disease also, then in determining the damages to be awarded for mental suffering or disease the jury must eliminate from consideration such of the plaintiff’s symptoms or demonstrations, if any, as could have been prevented by the exercise of such self control as the plaintiff was capable of at the time of such symptoms or demonstrations." (No discussion of statutory violations appears in the excerpt.)

**Ulwick v. DeChristopher**, 411 Mass. 4.proposition: Massachusetts law further requires that operators of motor vehicles exercise reasonable care to avoid foreseeable harm to others using the road.
**Ulwick v. DeChristopher**, 411 Mass. 4.support_reasoning: The opinion is about whether a social host owes a duty regarding an intoxicated guest’s later negligent driving; it does not articulate or discuss the general standard of care for motor vehicle operators. While the facts involve a drunk driver injuring a police officer, the court assumes that negligence without elaborating on Massachusetts’ general duty of reasonable care for motorists. Therefore, this case is not proper authority for the proposition that Massachusetts law requires motor vehicle operators to exercise reasonable care to avoid foreseeable harm to others on the road.

**Commonwealth v. Callahan**, 405 Mass..proposition: Bicyclists are recognized as lawful users of public ways and are entitled to the protections afforded by Massachusetts traffic and motor vehicle laws.
**Commonwealth v. Callahan**, 405 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion concerns whether a privately owned off‑road recreational area (“sand pits”) is a place to which the public has access as invitees or licensees for purposes of G.L. c. 90, §§ 24G(b) and 24(2)(a). It does not discuss bicycles, bicyclists, or their status as lawful users of public ways, nor does it interpret Massachusetts traffic or motor vehicle laws as applied to bicyclists. The holding is limited to construing the statutory locational requirement and distinguishing trespassers from invitees or licensees, so it does not support the claimed proposition about bicyclists’ rights on public ways.
**Commonwealth v. Callahan**, 405 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “We conclude that the ‘sand pits’ property on which the offenses occurred was not a ‘place to which the public has a right of access or . . . any place to which members of the public have access as invitees or licensees.’ Accordingly, we answer the reported question, ‘No.’ … ‘It is the status of the way, not the status of the driver, which the statute defines’.”

G.L. c. 85, \u00a7 11B.proposition: Bicyclists are recognized as lawful users of public ways and are entitled to the protections afforded by Massachusetts traffic and motor vehicle laws. See G.L. c. 85, § 11B (bicycles on public ways; rights and duties); Commonwealth v. Callahan, 405 Mass. 200, 202 (1989) (bicyclist as lawful roadway user).

**Jupin v. Kask**, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (2.proposition: Under Massachusetts common law, duty, breach, causation, and damages are the required elements of a negligence claim.
**Jupin v. Kask**, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (2.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely states the elements a plaintiff must prove to prevail on a negligence claim under Massachusetts law and lists duty, breach, damage, and causation in essentially the same formulation as the proposition. This statement is given as a general description of Massachusetts negligence law, citing a tort treatise, and is not limited to any special context, so it directly supports the claimed proposition.
**Jupin v. Kask**, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (2.relevant_excerpt: "To prevail on a negligence claim, a plaintiff must prove that the defendant owed the plaintiff a duty of reasonable care, that the defendant breached this duty, that damage resulted, and that there was a causal relation between the breach of the duty and the damage."

**Glidden v. Maglio**, 430 Mass. 694, 69.proposition: Under Massachusetts common law, duty, breach, causation, and damages are the required elements of a negligence claim.
**Glidden v. Maglio**, 430 Mass. 694, 69.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly identifies the elements the plaintiffs must prove for their negligence claims, listing breach of duty, actual loss (damages), and causation, and it treats duty as a prerequisite by discussing whether any duty existed. Although it does not recite the elements in a four-word formula, its articulation and analysis of duty, breach, causation, and damages as essential components of negligence squarely support the proposition about Massachusetts common-law negligence elements.
**Glidden v. Maglio**, 430 Mass. 694, 69.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiffs argue that they presented sufficient evidence to warrant a trial of each of their negligence claims. With respect to each such claim, the plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care, that the plaintiffs suffered actual loss, and that the defendant’s negligence caused their loss. … Causation is an essential element of that proof.”

**Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.raw_text: **Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc.**, 423 Mass. 637, 640 (1996)
**Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.proposition: Foreseeability of harm is central to the existence and scope of the duty of care.
**Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.case_name: Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.
**Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.support_reasoning: The concurrence explicitly frames the dispositive question as whether the plaintiff’s injuries were within the “reasonably foreseeable risk of harm” created by the defendant’s negligence, indicating that foreseeability defines the scope of the defendant’s duty in this context. While the quoted passage is brief and from a concurrence rather than the main opinion, it still reflects the court’s focus on foreseeability as central to determining duty and the limits of liability.
**Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.relevant_excerpt: “I concur in the view that ‘[t]he facts would not warrant a jury’s finding that the plaintiffs injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence.’ Ante at 640-641.”

**Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth.**.proposition: Foreseeability of harm is central to the existence and scope of the duty of care.
**Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth.**.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly frames liability around whether the third party’s wrongful conduct was foreseeable and applies the general rule that an intervening act does not break the chain of causation if it ought to have been foreseen. The court then upholds sending the case to the jury based on the foreseeability of unauthorized, intoxicated operation of the forklift and resulting harm to known pedestrians, making foreseeability central to defining both the existence and scope of the defendant’s duty. Thus, the case supports the proposition that foreseeability of harm is central to duty of care analysis.
**Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth.**.relevant_excerpt: “The general rule is that ‘[t]he act of a third person, intervening and contributing a condition necessary to the injurious effect of the original negligence, will not excuse the first wrongdoer, if such act ought to have been foreseen.… The test is to be found in the probable injurious consequences which were to be anticipated….’ … Under the facts of this case the jury would have been warranted in concluding that the actions of the seaman were foreseeable.… It was thus reasonably foreseeable that the forklift… would be operated by unauthorized persons… [and] that unauthorized operation would likely cause harm to persons known to pass through the area….”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Massachusetts applies a comparative negligence framework under G.L. c. 231, § 85, whereby a plaintiff’s contributory negligence does not bar recovery unless it is greater than the total negligence of the defendants; damages are diminished in proportion to the plaintiff’s comparative fault, if any.

**Grassi v. Femi**, 42 Mass. App. Ct. 91.proposition: A plaintiff is entitled to recover reasonable medical expenses, lost wages, property damage, and fair compensation for pain, suffering, and impairment causally related to the defendant’s negligence.

**Poirier v. Plymouth**, 374 Mass. 206,.proposition: A plaintiff is entitled to recover reasonable medical expenses, lost wages, property damage, and fair compensation for pain, suffering, and impairment causally related to the defendant’s negligence.
**Poirier v. Plymouth**, 374 Mass. 206,.support_reasoning: The quoted portion of Poirier v. Plymouth deals with premises liability and, specifically, the continued viability of the “hidden defect” rule. It does not address the categories of damages recoverable in negligence actions (medical expenses, lost wages, property damage, pain and suffering, or impairment), nor does it articulate any rule about entitlement to such damages. Therefore, this opinion does not support the cited proposition about recoverable damages.
**Poirier v. Plymouth**, 374 Mass. 206,.relevant_excerpt: This action was tried by the parties and submitted to the jury on the plaintiff’s claim that he was injured by reason of a hidden or concealed defect on the defendant’s premises, of which defect the defendant was aware or should have been aware through the exercise of reasonable care. The jury returned a substantial verdict for the plaintiff. The defendant appealed, contending that there was insufficient evidence to support the verdict… However, the court has chosen to go beyond that and has declared… that the “hidden defect” rule “no longer is to be applied in cases involving tort actions against landowners.”

**Goulet v. Whitin Mach. Works, Inc.**,.raw_text: **Goulet v. Whitin Mach. Works, Inc.**, 399 Mass. 547, 553 (1987)
**Goulet v. Whitin Mach. Works, Inc.**,.proposition: The question of negligence and comparative fault, where disputed, is generally one for the jury.
**Goulet v. Whitin Mach. Works, Inc.**,.case_name: Goulet v. Whitin MacHine Works, Inc.
**Goulet v. Whitin Mach. Works, Inc.**,.support_reasoning: The opinion deals with amendment of pleadings, breach of warranty, costs, and the correct method of calculating damages under comparative negligence, but it does not discuss who decides negligence or comparative fault (jury versus judge). The only mention of contributory negligence is in explaining how it affects damages and how it differs from unreasonable use in warranty claims. There is no statement that questions of negligence and comparative fault, when disputed, are generally for the jury, so the case does not support the claimed proposition.
**Goulet v. Whitin Mach. Works, Inc.**,.relevant_excerpt: "The jury found Whitin negligent but also found Goulet 50% contributorily negligent. The jury found that the total damages ‘which would have been recoverable by the plaintiff if there had been no contributory negligence attributable to the plaintiff’ were $225,000."

**Uloth v. City Tank Corp.**, 376 Mass..proposition: The question of negligence and comparative fault, where disputed, is generally one for the jury.
**Uloth v. City Tank Corp.**, 376 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss the general principle that negligence and comparative fault questions, when disputed, are for the jury. Instead, it focuses on product design negligence, adequacy of warnings, assumption of risk, and whether directed verdicts were proper based on the evidence, without articulating a broad rule about negligence/comparative fault being jury questions. The brief statement that assumption of risk is rarely decided as a matter of law is related but not the same proposition.
**Uloth v. City Tank Corp.**, 376 Mass..relevant_excerpt:
City Tank and Old Dominion also argue that their motions for directed verdicts and for judgments notwithstanding the verdicts should have been allowed because Uloth assumed the risk as matter of law.

Rarely, if ever, can it be said that a plaintiff has assumed the risk as matter of law.

... Although his testimony concerning his awareness of the danger of the packer panel was contradictory, resolution of conflicting testimony is the jury’s function.
